video.title: Solidity, Blockchain, and Smart Contract Course – Beginner to Expert Python Tutorial
video.description:
This course will give you a full introduction into all of the core concepts in blockchain, smart contracts, solidity, NFTs/ERC721s, ERC20s, Coding Decentralized Finance (DeFi), python and solidity, Chainlink, Ethereum, upgradable smart contracts, and full stack blockchain development. 

Follow along with the videos and you'll be a blockchain wizard in no time!

💻 The repository with helpful links to all code, resources, and support forums is located here: https://github.com/smartcontractkit/full-blockchain-solidity-course-py
Please reference the repo for anything you need, and feel free to leave issues, jump into the discussions, and more. 

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐
⌨️ (00:00:00) Introduction
⌨️ (00:06:33) Lesson 0: Welcome To Blockchain
⌨️ (01:31:00) Lesson 1: Welcome to Remix! Simple Storage
⌨️ (02:09:32) Lesson 2: Storage Factory
⌨️ (02:26:35) Lesson 3: Fund Me
⌨️ (03:26:48) Lesson 4: Web3.py Simple Storage
⌨️ (04:27:55) Lesson 5: Brownie Simple Storage
⌨️ (05:06:34) Lesson 6: Brownie Fund Me
⌨️ (06:11:38) Lesson 7: SmartContract Lottery
⌨️ (08:21:02) Lesson 8: Chainlink Mix
⌨️ (08:23:25) Lesson 9: ERC20s, EIPs, and Token Standards
⌨️ (08:34:53) Lesson 10: Defi & Aave
⌨️ (09:50:20) Lesson 11: NFTs
⌨️ (11:49:15) Lesson 12: Upgrades
⌨️ (12:48:06) Lesson 13: Full Stack Defi
⌨️ (16:14:16) Closing and Summary

✏️ Course developer by Patrick Collins, check out his YouTube channel for more great programming courses, blockchain education, and fun: https://www.youtube.com/c/patrickcollins

Follow Patrick!
🐦Twitter: https://twitter.com/PatrickAlphaC
📺YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCn-3f8tw_E1jZvhuHatROwA
✍️Medium: https://medium.com/@patrick.collins_58673/
💻GitHub: https://github.com/PatrickAlphaC
🏢LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/patrickalphac/

--

🎉 Thanks to our Champion and Sponsor supporters:
👾 Wong Voon jinq
👾 hexploitation
👾 Katia Moran
👾 BlckPhantom
👾 Nick Raker
👾 Otis Morgan
👾 DeezMaster
👾 AppWrite

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: cryzz0n
topLevelComment.text: Credit score is not something used in all countries though. In France, they determine if you are eligible to get a loan (e.g., to buy a house) based on the ratio between your salary, your expenses and your savings. Basically, if every month you 'burn' all your money, you're perceived as riskier than someone earning less but consistently making deposits to a saving account. I feel in the US people tend to buy things they don't need with money they don't have... The only times I feel one should need a credit is when buying 'big' things (house, car, etc.). Not for a TV. I’m 26 with over 800 credit score, time was put into that to build it up by Linuxtechcorps

replies.author: D S98

Hi

Really appreciate the work you put into this video, it's great.
I will like to notify a mistake: 1:36:40 -> 
1. uint256 
2. was specified first as an unsigned integer of 256 bits 
3. afterwards saying that the number assigned to this variable can be up to 256.

There are 2 possible ways to correct this:
- Correcting 2: unsigned integer of 8 bits
- Correcting 3: it can store an unsigned integer to up to (2 to power 256 - 1 -> that's the maximum unsigned that can be saved on 256 bits)

@John Cramer "single stocks" refers to buying one at a time, as opposed to index funds or mutual funds. 
It's still a gamble. Unless you can read the future, everytime you put money in a stock you risk it, and if it fails you can lose it.
Plus, studies show that people rarely ever beat the index, and if they do it usually isn't long. (We'll use the one Warren Buffet did as a source, but there are many) Sure, there are people who get rich doing this, but it's always a gamble. 

I forget if it's 90% or 95%, but casinos pay out a large portion of what's gambled, but most of that money goes to only a few, and oftentimes they gamble it away again. That doesn't make casino's an investment.

Now, the stocks you'd need to pull this off make it possibly worse, unless you got some insider knowledge I'm missing. The stable stocks like Apple, Google, and Microsoft aren't going to jump high enough to make this work. You'd be looking at les stabe stocks to pull this off. (Investing rule of thumb: Higher Risk = Higher Reward) With stocks, the risk is on things you can't control, (If you can control the stock you're investing in, there's a lot of laws being broken) so going high-risk is usually more problematic than it's worth, unless properly diversified. (Diversification also lowers return rates as well as loss. Hence why it's better to just go with an index fund than single stocks)

At the end of the day, can this work for you, possibly. Someone always wins the lottery, and some win it multiple times. Would I advise it, no. It'd be better to go with an index fund, or to find a way where you can control the risk.

topLevelComment.text: The regular lending rates on FTX are quite good compared to most banks, but they fluctuate by the hour (and also intra-hour, but you're generally not paid for that). Meanwhile staking is a set yearly amount that seldom changes, but then you have to find a good entry and bare the risk that entails. On the other hand, I consider the opportunity cost of not owning crypto these days to be much of a much higher risk. That is to say, I think _not _owning crypto is far more risky than owning it, due to various things not limited to stupid fiscal policies and Fed money printing. So the best is owing it, trading and investing with it, I learned that from a crypto expert from *Linux Tech Corps* I've made tons of profits btw

topLevelComment.text:
when adding the get account function at 4:57:25 i get the error 
string indices must be integers
it wont let me deploy from rinkeby but it works on the non persistent chains
SOLVED:
If anyone got this, you forgot a ":" on the brownie-config.yaml
in my case i put my private key right after the "from_key" identifier causing this error
the ":" allows the config reader to see that the private key value is seperate from the from_key: identifier

topLevelComment.author: Aditya Gupta
topLevelComment.text: Each node is the instancs of the decentralized network, does this means that each node has all the list of transaction happened in the network? Please answer this.

replies.author: Rafał Maciejewski
replies.text: @Aditya Gupta No because you only need to store the very last hash, the rest can be decoded from it

replies.author: Aditya Gupta
replies.text: @Rafał Maciejewski Thanks for this information. There are many block and each node has all the blocks. there will be a a storage problem. right?

replies.author: Rafał Maciejewski
replies.text: That is correct, let me explain why. The hash code in the last block of a chain, hashes the block number, the nonce and the "prev hash". Which means from the last block, you get the previous block's hash which in turn decodes the hash of the block before it, and so on and so forth... So effectively just from that single last hash you're able to rebuild the whole chain.

topLevelComment.author: Bruno Nunez
topLevelComment.text: Very fascinating talk, I particularly think the section on NFTs is interesting, after figuring out a little bit of what they are exactly it seems to that simply put NFTs are a way to digitally copyright digital assets.  It is interesting that even Vitalik at one point thought they were underrated because it almost seems like the glue that will end up tying cryptocurrencies together.  He is right that creators should have a way to "own" what they create.  coming from the standpoint of coding and working on 3d projects, copyrighting "assets" that are then potentially bought and sold with crypto seems very logical...  In game items for instance has already become a billion dollar industry, I played everquest since 1999 and used to get emails of lists of items people sold in game through paypal that later became the website IGN...  perfect concept for crypto and NFTs if it existed back then.. But the perfect way to get started now is invest with a trusted source *Virtualcryptomines🟡com*

      OR

topLevelComment.author: ubaid haroon
topLevelComment.text: at 2 hour and 13 mins, why did we create a variable type of SimpleStorage. What does it mean to create a variable type of SimpleStorage?

replies.author: David
replies.text: smart contracts are immutable; this means if we use a fix length array and it reach that limit then nothing else cannot be added to it and you cannot alter the length. So making it variable then you don't have to worry about hitting the limit and can store however much you'll like.

topLevelComment.author: Xarthgron
topLevelComment.text:
LINUX - USING TERMINAL COMMAND HISTORY. I'm not sure whether this works on other OSs.

As well as using the ↓ and ↑ arrow keys to go through past commands in the terminal, you can press CTRL + R and then type in part of the command.
The terminal will search your terminal history to complete the command as you type, then press ENTER.
This is useful if you have used a lot of other commands in the terminal so you don't have to press ↓ and ↑ many times.

If you have forgotten a command, you can type 'history' in the terminal, which will show you the last 1,000 terminal commands you used.

topLevelComment.author: Private
topLevelComment.text:
I am at 01:18:00 , can any correct me if I am wrong? 
The transaction fee is divided between all nodes but the block rewards are the block which only is given to the node who has mined first for the particular computational problem? In transaction fees, it doesn't matter who has mined first. The transaction will be divided equally into all nodes in a single p2p network but that is not the case in the block reward

replies.author: Scott
replies.text: To my knowledge, proof of work has all miners racing to the finish line, but only rewards the one that completes it first. Proof of stake, one gets "randomly" selected to perform the calculations and rewarded when complete.

replies.author: Dani Ihza Farrosi
replies.text:
As far as I know, it was because in smartcontract, it is bad to use 'float' value, since it will create unpredictable result value. 
Instead, we use int with big numbers to represent their decimals equivalent. I don't know about any library currently on how to do that, since it's a development environment specific (we input the value directly into smart contract, already calculated in -say- deploy.py). Hardhat or Truffle should be having this library feature. Brownie is less maintainable imo. 

After I finished this video, I'll move to Hardhat and adapt there, since it seems like more well maintained

topLevelComment.author: wardm4
topLevelComment.text:
I'd like to add that in the mid 50 minute mark it's said that "majority rules" on the blockchain and that's how we decide who is right. This isn't quite right. One of the most genius parts of blockchain is that we can tell which is right by checking which is longest. Because the computational power needed to produce a new block keeps getting harder, there is no way for a single entity to keep up with all the other people solving for the nonce. So if one person tries to maliciously change a block, they'll just fall behind on producing the rest of the chain and then we know they are the bad actor because their chain fell behind in length.

Of course, if 51% of miners all decide to change a block in the same way, then they could actually keep up, which is the concept of a 51% attack.

topLevelComment.author: Mohammed
topLevelComment.text:
11:49:15 Lesson 12: Upgrades
3(4?) Patterns of Upgrading:
1 -  Parametrise(setter methods to change value of existing state variables) or  use a contract registry(with a setter to update the address of the latest version of a smart contract)
2 - Social YEET/Migration(deploy new contract with upgrades and require all users to migrate over to it)
3 - Proxies(2 issues namely storage and function selector clashes) - subdivided into *Transparent Proxy Pattern* and *Universal Upgradeable Proxies Pattern(UUPS)*
All 3 methods can implement a governance contract to control changes.
4? - Diamond Pattern - if contract is exceeds max size you can split it up into multiple contracts.

replies.author: Binh Nguyen
replies.text: Finally found the answers, the receive function is only be executed when others send ether directly to your contract (not calling any function by code), the payable function can update the contract balance automatically when others call that function along with some values. And the callback function is being executed only if there is no receive function or the function being called by others do not exist in our contract.

topLevelComment.author: csybe
topLevelComment.text:
It gets really unclear here: https://youtu.be/M576WGiDBdQ?t=11323

"We sent this contract some money and there is no way to get it back"

First of all it's not clear what the fund() function is actually supposed to do. How about naming it something explicit, such as fundFromUserToDeveloper (if that's what it's supposed to do)?

Next, how can funds be sent to a contract? Where is the ether actually? It doesn't make sense to me who is new to blockchains.

So I don't understand why we need a withdraw function. Who is going to withdraw and from where?

Furthermore, this far into the tutorial I don't remember any explanation of Solidity explicit keywords (if they are keywords) such as address and msg.

Anyway, thanks for an otherwise great tutorial!

replies.author: csybe
replies.text: @Dani Ihza Farrosi well it doesn't really clarify anything. A ledger keeps track of things, yes, I already knew that. I didn't know you put actual money inside a ledger. Is that what's going on here? I'm now a few more hours into the tutorial and this transaction stuff is still not perfectly clear. It doesn't make sense to store a favorite number in a blockchain, which makes it hard to understand what's really going on. Sending funds from one person to another makes sense even in the real world. But each step should be explained why it is needed in the real world. Most of us know how you send money using a bank transaction, so a similar thing could be made with a blockchain. What's going on still needs to be explained. Not just how, but why it is done and what is actually going on.

replies.author: Dani Ihza Farrosi
replies.text: Fund is stored in the blockchain, which is a public ledger. Everyone has the book contains transaction from which address to another address. You're basically telling the blockchain that the transaction to this address belong to mine, and I can prove it.

topLevelComment.author: Matthew Feng
topLevelComment.text:
Note if you're stuck with send / transfer issues at 3:10    
If using Solidity 8.0+ (which you likely are due to the AggregatorV3Interface) you'll need to wrap msg.sender as payable(msg.sender) as in Solidity 8.0 addresses as payable by default anymore. So the finished line should look like: payable(msg.sender).transfer(address(this).balance);

topLevelComment.author: Johnnie Fujita
topLevelComment.text: on the pytest segment, for those not used to testing that may be wondering why to test. I want to point out that in this example Patrick indeed just called  directly the functions from the brownie framework, which is kind of redundant (he kind of tested a third party framework which is not really useful), but you should imagine a situation, that he packed all these function calls within a function defined by himself. Then you start testing your own code and whenever you make changes to it that changes the expected output, the test will fail and you will know right away that something is wrong.

topLevelComment.text: I ran into problem that solcx is not installed after I ran "pip install py-solc-x". Also, to run the deploy.py, I use "python3 deploy.py".

topLevelComment.author: BoomBoom - ブームブーム
topLevelComment.text: 31:50 Be careful, new created accounts inside an existing wallet adress wont be imported when using your seed phrase elsewhere, be aware of this. You need to manually export them and they'll generate a key (not seed phrase) for each account you export, so then you can import them again (using the import option in Metamask)

replies.author: BoomBoom - ブームブーム
replies.text: @Dev India nope that's not true, you can try if you want to but they're not linked, they live under the same Metamask account but definitely not linked one to another, it's just creating another side wallet. When a seed phrase is created it can't be modified, if they were linked to the same seed phrase it would have to change containing every single wallet that you create inside of Metamask. Those are imported wallet, completely different with their own generated key (like a seed phrase but without words, only a fixed length string)

replies.text: generate a key?? like a private key? I think both accounts would be linked to same phrase.

topLevelComment.author: Kevin Le
topLevelComment.text: I'm still a long way to complete all 16+ hours of the video. But I have this observation. At 18:30: If your computer and backup computers go down, in regular world, your data is gone. At 19:20: All you need to access your data is a private key, essentially a password. So if you store/save your private key/password in your computer/backup computers and they all go down (no human will be able to memorize the private key), then although your data is sill somewhere, but it's no good because you can't access it anyway. So if the solution is to save the private key in some cloud-based password manager company, then the control is just shifted from a bank to a cloud password company.

replies.author: revhappyrs2k
replies.text:
Found out how to properly install solc-x.  If you're on a Windows machine, open the python terminal.  Search for Python in Windows.  Open terminal and type in the following:
 from solcx import install_solc
I received the following error:
INFO: Could not find files for the given pattern(s).
So I typed in the following (again in the Python terminal)
install_solc('v0.6.0')
It should then show the version number in the terminal.
And that did the trick.  Hope it works for you as well!

replies.author: revhappyrs2k
replies.text: Yes, I'm having the same issue with solcx.  It says version 0.6 is not installed although it pip installs successfully.  My guess is it has something to do with version numbers, reading the documentation it shows it downloads all relevant version up to 1.1.0 but sets one as active.  I find the commands to check for the active version but they're not working in the Terminal nor in the Python set script.  I'll try to share if I find the solution and would hope if you find the solution, you would post it up as well!  Good Luck!

replies.author: CneqVR
replies.text:
@TradeLion I'm surprised you're on a technology channel and are still somehow oblivious to the process of technological evolution.

The move from horses to cars created problems that could only be fixed by drastic change and same can be said with planes, the internet and just about every technological innovation.

There are always going to be problems caused by attempting to harness a new disruptive technology and that is simply the process as it always has been and it is no different with the new innovations being made with DLT.

Although in the case of DLT the process of it's integration into existing ecosystems will in my opinion prove much more easy than a transition for horses to cars, after all, the ecosystems DLT hopes to integrate with have already undergone the harsh adaption required when they were forced to adapt to all other information technologies and thus there isn't much left other than acceptance for further integration.

replies.text: @Choice When he begins coding, he brushes over many basic concepts in programming, and speaks more in depth about what we are actually programming in terms of blockchain, smart contracts, etc. So, for someone with no coding experience you may not fully grasp what the code is doing, or the syntax involved. Solidity is very similar to JavaScript in terms of syntax, but most object oriented programming languages such as these include the same concepts and capabilities so it is rather universal. I would recommend learning the basics of JavaScript and python for this course.

replies.text: Just a little clarification, int can be a negative and postive number, uint is the negative number added with the postive number into a combined postive number, without the ability of going into negative numbers. so int has a range of -1 to +1 while uint has a range of 0 to 2 (without using the actual real numbers) because its many :P

topLevelComment.author: Oleg Morket
topLevelComment.text:
Thank you, awesome! Looking forward to the JS version. Any hint when that might be?
Extra question: is front-end expertise (React, Vue) useful if one were to broaden one's skills into Solidity, blockchain and all of that? Is there such a thing as full stack Web3 engineeer?

replies.author: Oleg Morket
replies.text: @Vinay Mirchandanifor that you basically just wanna run a node on the network. You may wanna watch the first 90 minutes or so of this video to gain an understanding of how the blockchain network works in general. He explains it well. And running a node is not that complicated, you don't need to be a developer. If you wanna run the node for profit though, to the best of my understanding, it's not a very viable project with an ordinary computer. You want specialized hardware and cheap electricity. And that would apply to proof of work networks, the kind everybody is trying to get away from. So gradually they might disappear

replies.author: Patrick Collins
replies.text: @Vinay Mirchandani We don't do much of the hardware side, no. Just the smart contract/software side.
